title: Mind-body interventions - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: (MBI) or mind-body training (MBT) [[1]](#cite_note-NCCIH_2014-1) [[2]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_LM_Al.-2) are health and fitness [interventions](/wiki/Therapy) that are intended to work on a physical and mental level such as [yoga](/wiki/Yoga), [tai chi](/wiki/Tai_chi), and [Pilates](/wiki/Pilates). [[3]](#cite_note-Jung_Ha-3) [[4]](#cite_note-Lee_Mancuso-4) [[5]](#cite_note-Gruicic_Benton_pp._798-814-5) The in September 2000 by the [United States](/wiki/United_States) [National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health](/wiki/National_Center_for_Complementary_and_Integrative_Health) government agency, and encompasses [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) interventions. [[6]](#cite_note-Online_Version-6) It excludes scientifically validated practices such as [cognitive behavioral therapy](/wiki/Cognitive_behavioral_therapy). [Cochrane](/wiki/Cochrane_(organisation)) reviews have found that studies in this area are small and have low scientific validity. [[7]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_J_Al._2017-7) [[8]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_JS_Al._2014-8) [[9]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_A_Al._2013-9) [[10]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_Z_Al._2017-10) [[11]](#cite_note-Cochrane_2016-11) [[12]](#cite_note-Cebolla_Demarzo_Martins_Soler_p=e0183137-12) Since 2008, authors documenting research conducted on behalf of the NCCIH have used terms mind and body practices and mind-body medicine interchangeably with mind-body intervention to denote [therapies](/wiki/Therapy), as [physical](/wiki/Physical_medicine_and_rehabilitation) and [mental](/wiki/Psychiatric_rehabilitation) rehabilitative practices, which "focus on the relationships between the brain, mind, body, and behavior, and their effect on health and disease." [[13]](#cite_note-pmid23227136-13) According to the NCCIH, "mind and body practices include a large and diverse group of procedures or techniques administered or taught by a trained practitioner or teacher". [[14]](#cite_note-14) Definitions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Mind%E2%80%93body_interventions&action=edit§ion=1)] The [United States and Integrative Health (NCCIH) defines mind-body interventions as activities that purposefully affect mental and physical fitness, listing activities such as yoga, tai chi, pilates, [guided imagery](/wiki/Guided_imagery), [guided contains 3 systematic reviews that explicitly cite and define MBI as MBT. [[18]](#cite_note-pmidhttps://doi.org/10.1002/14651858.CD007559.pub2-18) despite them focusing more strictly on the mind. One review uses a narrower definition, defining MBT as an 'active' intervention in which mental and physical exercises are alternated. [[2]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_LM_Al.-2) A web search will yield mentions of mind-body training in offerings of entities that give yoga, pilates, or meditation training, but explicit definitions are rare.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Origins and history[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Mind%E2%80%93body_interventions&action=edit§ion=2)] Western MBI was popularized in the early 20th century but dates back to [Ancient Greece](/wiki/Ancient_Greece). [[19]](#cite_note-Hoffman_Gabel_2015_p.-19) The Greek values of strength and beauty in combination with [Greek mythology](/wiki/Greek_mythology) led to activities intended to promote confidence.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Eastern MBI in the form of [yoga](/wiki/Yoga) originated in [Ancient India](/wiki/Ancient_India) and has been around since at least 500 BCE and possibly as early as 3300 BCE. [[20]](#cite_note-Crangle_1994_p.-20) [[21]](#cite_note-Zimmer_Campbell_1951_p.-21) [[22]](#cite_note-Samuel_2008_p.-22) A renewed interest developed in mind-body work in the late 19th and early 20th century. Possibly due to visits from yoga gurus and increased interest, some medical practitioners and movement specialists developed movement therapies with a deliberate mental focus. [[19]](#cite_note-Hoffman_Gabel_2015_p.-19) Two prominent names in modern mind-body training are [Joseph Pilates](/wiki/Joseph_Pilates) (1880-1967) and [Margaret Morris](/wiki/Margaret_Morris_(dancer)) (1891-1980). A famous statement of Joseph Pilates was "Physical fitness is the first requisite of happiness." [[23]](#cite_note-Morris_Jeayes_2003_p.-23) Margaret Morris had a background in dance and claimed a connection between a free dance and a free mind. [[19]](#cite_note-Hoffman_Gabel_2015_p.-19) [[24]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_P_Al._2018-24) In conventional medicine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Mind%E2%80%93body_interventions&action=edit§ion=3)] All mind-body interventions focus on the interaction between the [brain](/wiki/Brain), [body](/wiki/Human_body), and [behavior](/wiki/Behavior) and are practiced with intention to use the [mind](/wiki/Mind) to alter physical function and promote overall [health](/wiki/Health) and [well-being](/wiki/Well-being). [[25]](#cite_note-pmid21116746-25) [[26]](#cite_note-pmid21717826-26) However, the [NCCIH](/wiki/National_Center_for_Complementary_and_Integrative_Health) does not consider mind-body interventions as within the purview of complementary and alternative medicine when there is sufficient [scientific evidence](/wiki/Scientific_evidence) for the benefit of such practices along with their professional application in [conventional medicine](/wiki/Medicine). [Cognitive behavioral therapy](/wiki/Cognitive_behavioral_therapy) is defined by the NCCIH as a mind-body intervention because it utilizes the [mind](/wiki/Mind)'s capacity to affect bodily function and [symptoms](/wiki/Symptom), but also there is sufficient [scientific evidence](/wiki/Scientific_evidence) and [mainstream application](/wiki/Medicine) for it to fall outside the purview of complementary and alternative medicine. [[6]](#cite_note-Online_Version-6) Evidence for efficacy[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Mind%E2%80%93body_interventions&action=edit§ion=4)] Most studies of MBI and related techniques are small and have low scientific validity, a finding that dominates many [Cochrane Reviews](/wiki/Cochrane_Reviews). [[7]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_J_Al._2017-7) [[8]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_JS_Al._2014-8) [[9]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_A_Al._2013-9) [[10]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_Z_Al._2017-10) [[11]](#cite_note-Cochrane_2016-11) [[12]](#cite_note-Cebolla_Demarzo_Martins_Soler_p=e0183137-12) Some of the individual studies do show positive results, but this may be due to chance or placebo effects and the significance may diminish when groups are randomized. Proponents of MBI techniques suggest that a rationale for mind-body training is that the mind follows the body and the body follows the mind. The body-mind connection can be attributed to hormones and chemicals released during movement, [[27]](#cite_note-Leisman_Moustafa_Shafir_p.-27) although the mind-body connection is dominated by the brain and is considered to be more of a neurological mechanism. There are some indications that movement complexity may have an impact on brain development. [[28]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_T_Al._2019-28) When it comes to explicitly alternating mental and physical exercise sections, proponents rationalize that physical activity induces an elevated heart-rate and increases in stress, which mimics conditions in which athletes need their mental skills the most. [[29]](#cite_note-Welcome_to_2Mynds-29) It is believed that these conditions make training more functional and there is some limited scientific evidence supporting effectiveness because of this type of approach. [[2]](#cite_note-pubmeddev_LM_Al.-2) There are documented benefits of several mind-body interventions derived from [scientific research](/wiki/Scientific_method): first, by MBI use contributing to the treatment a range of conditions including [headaches](/wiki/Headache), [coronary artery disease](/wiki/Coronary_artery_disease) and [chronic [physical pain](/wiki/Pain) in patients with [cancer](/wiki/Cancer); third, in increasing the perceived capacity to [cope](/wiki/Coping_(psychology)) with significant problems and challenges; and fourth, in improving the reported overall [quality of life](/wiki/Quality_of_life). In addition, there is evidence supporting the [brain](/wiki/Brain) and [central nervous system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system)'s influence on the [immune system](/wiki/Immune_system) and the capacity for mind-body interventions to enhance [immune function](/wiki/Immune_system) outcomes, including defense against rarely reported in mind-body training. Some studies have indicated that meditation can have undesired adverse effects on specific clinical populations (e.g., people with a history of [PTSD](/wiki/PTSD)), although these are smaller studies. [[37]](#cite_note-Lindahl_Fisher_Cooper_Rosen_p=e0176239-37) [[38]](#cite_note-Schlosser_Sparby_Vörös_Jones_p=e0216643-38) There is limited high-quality evidence as well with regard to the effect of intensity and duration. In a small study observing 87 healthy female participants undergoing either mind-body training or no training, [[3]](#cite_note-Jung_Ha-3) participants who actively participated in an online program showed significantly greater resilience toward stress, anger, anxiety, and depression at 8 weeks than at 4 weeks into the study. [[3]](#cite_note-Jung_Ha-3) However, this study was not randomized and the placebo effect may be large on the subjective psychological test scores. [[39]](#cite_note-39) Recent meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials (RTCs) confirmed the efficacy of smartphone interventions for mental health problems, including depression, anxiety, and stress.
